review.title: Learning Language Representations for Typology Prediction
review.abstract: One central mystery of neural NLP is what neural models "know" about their subject matter. When a neural machine translation system learns to translate from one language to another, does it learn the syntax or semantics of the languages? Can this knowledge be extracted from the system to fill holes in human scientific knowledge? Existing typological databases contain relatively full feature specifications for only a few hundred languages. Exploiting the existence of parallel texts in more than a thousand languages, we build a massive many-to-one neural machine translation (NMT) system from 1017 languages into English, and use this to predict information missing from typological databases. Experiments show that the proposed method is able to infer not only syntactic, but also phonological and phonetic inventory features, and improves over a baseline that has access to information about the languages' geographic and phylogenetic neighbors.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The linguistic typology is the classification of human languages by syntactic, phonological and other classes of traits, and the study of the relationships and correlations between these classes / traits. This study is a scientific pursuit in its own right since the 19th century (Greenberg, 1963; Comrie, 1989; Nichols, 1992), but recently the typology has borne practical fruit in various sub-sections of the NLP, in particular on problems affecting languages with lower resources. 1Code and learned vectors are available at http: / / github.com / chaitanyamalaviya / lang-repsTypological information from sources such as the World Atlas of Language Structures (WALS), 2013. They have proven useful in many NLP tasks (O'Horan et al., 2016), such as multilingual dependencies parsing (Ammar et al., 2016), parsing in settings with low resources.

sections.heading: 2 Dataset and Experimental Setup
sections.text: Typology Database: To perform our analysis, we use the URIEL Language Typology Database (Littell et al., 2017), which is a collection of binary characteristics taken from several typological, phylogenetic and geographical databases such as WALS (World Atlas of Language Structures) (Collins and Kayne, 2011), PHOIBLE (Moran et al., 2014), Ethnologue (Lewis et al., 2015) and Glottolog (Hammarstro ¼ m et al., 2015), which are divided into separate classes in terms of syntax (e.g. whether a language has prepositions or postpositions), phonology (e.g. whether a language has complex syllabic clusters) and phonetic inventory (e.g. whether a language has interdental friction). There are 103 syntactic characteristics, 28 phonological characteristics and 158 phonetic characteristics in the databases.

sections.heading: 4.1 Multilingual Data and Training Regimen
sections.text: To train a multilingual neural machine translation system, we used a corpus of Bible translations obtained by scraping a huge online Bible database on bible.com. [5] This corpus contains data for 1017 languages. After pre-processing the corpus, we received a training set of 20.6 million sentences across all languages. Implementation of both the LM and NMT models described in § 3 was done in the DyNet toolkit (Neubig et al., 2017). In order to obtain a manageable common vocabulary for all languages, we shared the data using common byte-pair encoding of all languages (Sennrich et al., 2016) with 32-K merge operations. [We4We] also tried to use the mean of the final hidden cell states of the LSTM encoder, but the mean cell state across all the words in the sentence yielded an improved performance, but we found that, in addition, the representative states of the encoder LSTM were not present.

sections.heading: 4.2 Results and Discussion
sections.text: The results of the study are indeed remarkable, because they show that most people are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they do not want.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: Through this study, we have shown that neural models can learn a range of linguistic concepts and can be used to insinuate missing features in typological databases. In particular, we have demonstrated the usefulness of learning representations with parallel text, and the results indicate the importance of modelling the dynamics of representation as models process sentences. We hope that this study will encourage the additional use of typological features in downstream NLP tasks and inspire further techniques to predict missing knowledge in poorly documented languages.
